posts.cooked: The team is transitioning from a REV drivetrain to a CTRE system using Kraken components. They noticed issues with heading accuracy after updating to the Pigeon 2 platform. Implementing the zeroHeading() method corrected initial directional control, but during a 180-degree turn, wheels deviated to lateral movement instead of straight ahead. Further investigation is needed to identify potential errors in the zeroHeading() implementation, with the project available on GitHub for reference.

posts.name: gartaud

link_counts.title: Properly Setting Gyro Yaw when Robot is being placed on the field

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: Not from CTRE, but here's how I do this on my team: To set a pose on the field, use SwerveDrivetrain.resetPose(Pose2d). This also resets the gyro to the angle you tell it without anything else necessary. To set the forward direction, use SwerveDrivetrain.setOperatorPerspectiveForward(Rotation2d).

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Thank you! If we want the forward direction to be the default—that is, towards the opposing alliance—would calling resetPose() be enough? Does resetPose() have an impact on the forward direction that might require adjustment?

What is your understanding of seedFieldCentric() compared to resetPose()?

Do you have a public code example that we could review?

posts.name: Gina W
posts.cooked:
The text is:

For more context/understanding of our situation, heres a video of our drivetrain (Robot is supposedly only going forward and backward here): https://youtu.be/OgQqy80djuQ?si=ZPojjXuoEMIV-raI

**Step-by-step explanation:** 1. **Remove HTML tags:** Take out the `

` tag that encloses the entire paragraph. 2. **Keep only the essential content:** Retain the sentence "For more context/understanding of our situation, heres a video..." along with the embedded link. 3. **Format correctly:** Ensure the link appears inline after the colon without additional explanations. 4. **Grammar and punctuation:** Maintain correct grammar and punctuation throughout the resulting single, continuous paragraph. 5. **Final output:** The result is a concise, grammatically correct paragraph containing only the requested information.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
With CTRE, the operator's forward direction is field relative, so it isn’t affected by the robot’s rotation.

Let’s say you’re on the blue alliance. You position your robot on the starting location, facing the blue alliance driver station (i.e., a field-relative rotation of 180 degrees). Calling resetPose() with the correct position (with a rotation of 180 degrees) will tell the robot where it is. Therefore, the robot’s estimated field-relative pose will align with its real field-relative pose.

From there, let’s say you drive in teleop using a SwerveRequest.FieldCentric request. By default, it uses whatever the drivetrain’s operator forward perspective is. In the codebase provided by the original poster, the code to set the forward direction is automatically generated by CTRE, and it’s on CommandSwerveDrivetrain.java, line 275. This means that applying that request with velocity of (x: 1, y: 1) will cause the robot to move (from the field’s point of view) one meter per second away from the blue alliance wall (positive x), and one meter per second in the positive y direction, from the field’s point of view.

Adding nonzero operator forward directions can cause different behavior. For example, we have a button on our controller that resets the operator forward direction to the robot’s current field-relative orientation. The end result of this is that telling the robot to travel with an x velocity of 1 and y velocity of 0 causes the robot to travel in the direction that it was facing when we applied the new operator forward direction. Even if the robot rotates as it drives, it will always treat +x as in the direction of the operator forwards perspective from a global, field-relative POV.

What this does is tells the robot “you’re now facing away from the blue alliance”. The robot says “okay” and then resets its odometry to match. If you’re in a match and you give it the wrong angle, this can make the robot very confused because all of its pose estimation (besides vision) comes from the robot-relative chassis speeds. To turn robot-relative chassis speeds into field-relative chassis speeds, you need an accurate measure of the robot’s field relative orientation.

All of what I’m saying is used in our codebase here.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Thank you. Everything is clear except that paragraph:  
Assuming no vision is involved to simplify the scenario, while the estimated field-relative pose would obviously not align with the real field-relative pose anymore, why would the robot be very confused?  

And did you get a chance to look at the video? If the initial pose is correct, why would the robot lose track of where forward is when it spins on itself?

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
IMPORTANTLY DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION) JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH.

The text is:

The robot calculates field-relative position by measuring its velocity and integrating it over time. Each tick, it measures its robot-relative velocity in x and y directions, converts it to field-relative via "unrotating" based on its measured angle, then multiplies by time difference (0.02s) to find position change. New position equals old plus delta. Accurate field-relative rotation is critical for this conversion; incorrect rotation causes the robot to miscalculate direction. Over time, this error can cause inaccurate pose estimation leading to confusion in decision-making. I suggest using built-in CTRE methods like Forward Perspective and resetPose for better handling. Testing involves resetting rotation and verifying behavior. Note that zeroHeading might reverse the robot's forward direction intentionally.

---

The cleaned-up version:

The robot calculates field-relative position by measuring its velocity and integrating it over time. Each tick, it measures its robot-relative velocity in x and y directions, converts it to field-relative via "unrotating" based on its measured angle, then multiplies by time difference (0.02s) to find position change. New position equals old plus delta. Accurate field-relative rotation is critical for this conversion; incorrect rotation causes the robot to miscalculate direction. Over time, this error can cause inaccurate pose estimation leading to confusion in decision-making. I suggest using built-in CTRE methods like Forward Perspective and resetPose for better handling. Testing involves resetting rotation and verifying behavior. Note that zeroHeading might reverse the robot's forward direction intentionally.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked: Thank you again. I wasn't able to attend the event myself, but from what I gathered, it seems like a rook transforming into a bishop in chess terms when its orientation changes. We'll receive more information next week regarding whether the gyro angle and pose remain synchronized. oppositeHeading() does rotate by 180 degrees, which makes sense for when the robot faces the driver during the upcoming matches.

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
The text is:

More specifically, seedFieldCentric() tells the robot that it’s now facing in the direction of the Rotation2d that was provided to setOperatorPerspectiveForward(). The operator perspective should always be set to Rotation2d.kZero on the Blue Alliance and Rotation2d.k180deg on the Red Alliance, and seedFieldCentric() should be called after setting the operator perspective forward. Alternatively, resetRotation(Rotation2d) always takes a field-centric rotation (0 deg is away from blue, 180 deg is away from red).

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: jweston
posts.cooked:
Are the module wheels all facing the same angle or are they at different angles?  

I ask because if the module encoders are at different angles, consider securing them. If they are aligned, it’s more likely related to an IMU issue.  

To check if the module encoders are drifting, draw a sharpie line across each magnet toward the edge of its holder. Spin the wheels and realign the lines. If misaligned after spinning, secure the magnets to prevent drift with double-sided tape.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked: Thank you. It turned out that calling `reset()` on the pigeon before it was completely reset caused issues because `tareEverything()` was called too early. Since we no longer need to reset the pigeon, we removed those problematic calls, and everything is functioning correctly. Initially, we thought that `reset()` without a timeout would suffice, but it seems that assumption didn't hold true.

posts.name: jweston
posts.cooked: Yeah, the timing on some Pigeon calls can be a bit tricky. I’ve found it works best when resetting() only during a robot constructor or initialization phase, followed by calling tareEverything() in either automatic or teleop mode. Reset() is non-blocking, so taring out odometry values while resetting() is active ensures accurate measurements.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
After competing off-season, today our mediocre robot was upgraded with a full CTRE drivetrain featuring the same MK4i swerve modules, replacing the encoder and NavX combo with a Kraken/CANcoders/Pigeon 2 combo on a CANIvore bus. We're extremely satisfied with your product; it just works perfectly.

We wish we'd had this system from the beginning. Thank you.
